Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I'm just your standard music lover that loves her music clean, crisp and clear when i put on a pair of headphones. I've owned this very headphone before and kept them for 10 years when they suddenly grew legs and walked away. (Someone took them-but i digress) to replace them i've had some suggestions of newer models and in my research i found those suggestions entirely over priced but went to various retailers to test drive them anyway. The Dr Dre beats and the Skull Candy's looked (with all their colors and patterns) better than they sounded..LOTS of bass! but i suppose that's what the kids go for these days. The Bose really weren't all that impressive either, they sounded decent but not in comparison to what i already knew was a great quality headphone for WAY cheaper. These headphones ... sound clear in the highs and lows and theres enough bass for any recording without overwhelming the original intent of the music. They have a cool retro studio look that are lighter on the head then any pictures would appear, with super soft ear pads that are quite comfortable and remain so for extended periods of listening. One word of advice tho... These headphones sound better when broken in... do this by playing music in them for about 5 hours straight at a good volume... loud but not blasting- just plug them in and walk away for awhile and they will sound PERFECT quickly for you. Buy these! you shan't regret it! Why spend entirely too much for the latest trendy high priced mediocre equipment when you can have a high quality product for a very good low price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I use these headphones on daily basis while programming and doing design work. PROS: They have quality construction and look pretty durable. The ear muffs fit right over the entire ear so pretty good for external noise reduction. Sound is good, I am just running them directly from my iMac so I assume if they are plugged into a nice amp, will sound better. They fold down for easy storage. CONS: The ears sweat inside if worn for any long period of time. The folding feature can get very annoying when trying to put the headphones on, they keep folding in and flipping around. The coiled wire is not comfortable because it keeps getting in the way, only about 4 foot long when not stretched out. OVERALL THOUGHTS: I am willing to deal with the annoying ear sweating, folding and wire getting in ... the way for a good quality pair of earphones, which I think this is. I got them at a good deal at B&H and have nothing to complain about. Will not be able to get other better or even equal quality headphones for that price. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 3 out of 3 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I've used the MDR-V6, MDR-V600 and MDR 7506 headphones. Of the three, the MDR-V6 is the best balance of value and performance. Yesterday I wore the V6 models for 8 hours and they were comfortable. They fold neatly and stow easily in their carry bag. I used a pair of these for years in my previous video production job. Their sound is well-balanced and with the closed ear design they offer acoustic isolation from your surroundings so you can really hear what you're recording. The plug tip that unscrews to change from 1/4 to 1/8 is extremely handy. Overall, these are superb sounding, comfortable and durable headphones when treated with any reasonable degree of care. I did notice that yanking too hard on the ear cup material can pull it off the body of the phones, but it's easy to put ... it back in place. I own the V600 models at home, but they're a bit bulkier and the V6 models are more convenient for field use. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Good Headphones, But not Great fit
Item.Review: These are some pretty great headphones. They have a very good sound, a little colored in the low end, but other wise very clean. The mids and highs are very clear and the lows are responsive and present. The only thing I don't like about these headphones is the fit. They fit very loose around my head. I had to push them up against my head to get a good fit. Other than the fit, these are very good headphones for the price.

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Light weight; Folding design for easier storage; Great audio frequency range; Great aural frequency response; Incredible sound quality; Quality sound reproduction; Long cable
Cons: None
It is going to be near-impossible to review these headphones without fawning so I won't even bother going around it: These headphones are amazing. Sony really have out-done themselves here. For $70 USD, I got headphones that can easily compete with BOSE headphones near the same price, but cost less in the end anyway. Starting with something nearly as important as sound-quality: comfortability. These headphones are just a delight. Straight out of the box, the cushions were already soft enough where I wore them for 12 hours after this unboxing and I just barely felt them. The adjustment sy ... stem is really good as well, allowing many, many notches of adjustment which are very precise in positioning. Build quality now. Metal. That's right, Sony didn't fool around with these headphones. The adjusting rail is metal, the headphone enclosure is metal, and the folding mecahnism is metal. Even the plastic pieces, the outer-rim of the earphone enclosure and the earphone mounts, are sturdy and thick. Now to the reason why you should buy these headphones: sound quality. These headphones can produce a soundrange beyond human hearing capabilities and can truly send a powerful signal. It handles bass like a dream and treble comes through crisp and clear. Perfect for 320kbps/FLAC listening.
**Get these headphones. **They will change how you listen to audio. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Well constructed & great sounding! I've owned MDR-V6 cans for many years and am considering purchasing another for my wife who has been experiencing headaches with her ear buds. As a programmer who sits at a desk for extended periods, I can have these on all day with no issues. They cover my ears entirely and inherently block out surrounding noises. The cord is coiled so it's not in the way and when it is it's is easy to flip aside. The bottom end doesn't sound muddled/processed - very clear & precise! As a matter in fact, I look forward to listening to music with these just so I can "hear" what I imagine the sound reproduction was intended to be.
Cons: Vinyl ear cushions will deteriorate.
I did a lot of research to find a good set of cans and for the price ... these topped the charts. Now, I'm at least 8 years running with these, no issues! I didn't wait for the ear cushions to deteriorate, I replaced the originals almost the day I purchased the cans with Beyerdynamic DT-250 (now I think they are 7506) velour replacements. I recently started looking for a set for my wife and didn't expect these to still be available. Very happy to Sony still pumping these. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review:
Pros: Great aural frequency response; Incredible sound quality; Light weight; Folding design for easier storage; Quality sound reproduction; Great audio frequency range
Sony MDR-V6 headphones are studio grade dynamic stereo headphones. They are very popular among the mid range of audiophiles and used in professional studios and by directors around the globe.
The padding on the headrest is very light and not overly tight but provides a high amount of comfort. The headphones also have adjusters that can easily become the right size unlike many other constricting headphones out there.
The padding on the earcups is also very plush and soft against the ears/head.
The sound quality is where ths MDR-V6 headphones shine. The mid range is extremely solid and has a slight ... warmth to it. Highs dont seem to go as high as Sennheisers px100 in my opinion but sounds just as crisp. The bass is full and not overdramatic without any rollouts. They have depth unlike skullcandy ear/headphones. With an equalizer/bass booster the bass output can increase without losing it's depth.
Also it comes with a coiled cord that is very, and I mean very long. Over 2 yards long if you really pull it all the way. Can't say I understand that. Do music artists a favor and listen to the way it was meant to sound. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I'm a studio engineer/producer/musician. I've had my MDR-V6 phones for over 20 years, and they still sound terrific. There are only two downsides (and these are both well-known shortcomings): ??? The 1/8 to 1/4 plug adapter breaks too easily???usually after a few years if you use it often. Just get yourself a good plug adapter and that takes care of it. (The built-in 1/8 stereo mini-plug is rock-solid with good strain relief.) ??? The ear pad covering eventually breaks down and the pads need to be replaced (mine lasted 15 years). But the pads are available online for about $5, and it takes just a few minutes to remove the old ones and install the new ones. (No tools or special skills required.) Even so, 15 years of steady service for earpads is pretty darned good???and the phones thems ... elves are still going strong. Now, let me explain to you why these phones have been the choice of many studio mix engineers for the past couple of decades. It's NOT because they have perfectly flat response (they don't, but except for a 5 dB dip at about 5kHz and a 5 db bump at about 9kHz, they're pretty close), or because they have great ambient noise rejection (they don't), or because they're super comfortable (they're much better than average, but there are more comfortable phones). Rather, the reason these phones are so valuable in the studio is because you can hear things on them that you can't hear on other phones. I don't mix on them, but I CHECK my mixes on them, and without exception, they reveal things that I otherwise wouldn't hear...even on my state of the art tri-amped Genelec studio monitors. The imaging is excellent -- very clear and tight (not time-smeared or smushed). That's especially true in the bass and mid-bass range, where so many other headphones fail. I don't want killer bass; I want ACCURATE bass. Sony probably could have tweaked the ample 40 mm drivers to deliver more bass, but I'm grateful they chose to stick with accuracy. The bass response is smooth, ultra-realistic, and super clean. I have no idea how these phones compare to what an audiophile would want. I only know that the music audiophiles listen to (if it's well mixed), was probably checked on a pair of MDR-V6 (or MDR-7506) phones. (They're essentially the same.) Now you know the secret...the reason why these phones are legendary, and deservedly so. In fact, I've become so accustomed to the vivid clarity of the MDR-V6 phones that I use them for everything...even everyday listening. They're simply superb phones for that purpose --- better than any other phones I've ever used. If you want phones that do something different --- like explosive bass response or other coloration --- then these aren't for you. But if you want a set of super-durable phones that will reveal musical detail in a way that most other phones can't --- especially at such a remarkably reasonable price --- you'll be hard pressed to find another set of phones (except MDR-7506) that even comes close. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Best headphones I have ever owned
Item.Review: I have gone through countless sets of headphones and gaming headsets, and I had finally had enough. I've owned earplugs, over-ear headphones and around-ear headphones, and the MDR-V6 is by far the best set I have ever owned. I have had these for 2 years now, dropped them many times and they show no signs of wear or tear. The majority of the construction is of lightweight metal which makes these headphones incredibly durable, which was one of my two biggest concerns when forking out[$] (at the time). My other concern was long-term comfort. When wearing these headphones for several hours, your ears don't get flattened or hurt or sweaty, they are comfy the entire time. I can not think of anything bad to say about these headphones, and I am a very picky shopper. The cable, padding, asthetics, ... weight, and even the stereo plug are of exceptional quality. I really like that the headphones are naturally 1/8 stereo and have a screw-on 1/4 stereo plug that goes right over the 1/8 one. Because it screws on, the connection is tight and you don't have to worry about losing the adapter. It even comes with a little bag. I would have been happy paying up to 1.5x for these headphones. Also, these block out external sounds exceptionally well. In fact, I rarely wear these with both ears covered because if someone was in the room talking to me, I wouldn't hear them! These are great for loud areas and they have good highs and lows (bass) while not being overbearing. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: The MDR V6s with the Velour mod cannot be beat at the price point of sub 100. Simply amazing sound, comfort and construction. I love that they fold up so easy so that you can fit them easily in smaller spaces, and how long the cable coils out to. The velour pad mod allows for much better comfort after hours of use. Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I've had these headphones for around a month now and they have been great to me. At first I was underwhelmed at the sound quality but it took about 4-5 days for them to really start to sound how I expected them to sound. I mainly use them for listening to music, producing and mixing (although I'm no pro). For general music listening these are fantastic. Great clear highs, distinguishable mids, and the perfect lows. Some people say there isn't that umph when it comes to the bass but an EQ would fix that. As far as producing goes, it does tend to get some static noise on low volume tracks. This doesn't happen all the time, maybe 10% of the time. Mixing sometimes gets a bit touch as far as beatmatching goes. You have to have an EQ to distinguish the bass or kicks in the tracks. They also d ... on't swivel left to right, so if there are any professional DJ's out there you might want to think twice. These headphones aren't built to withstand punishment. If your the kind to drop headphones frequently these might not be for you. The wires connecting to each ear cup are exposed (around 4 inches in length). These are very comfortable headphones. They're not too heavy and not too light. I have a pretty big head and these fit perfectly. You can even head bang if you want and not force them to fall off. They fold up very nicely for travel. A lot of people have had problems with the covers on the pads. Since I've had them for a month I haven't noticed them tear off so far. I'll update my review as soon as I start noticing the cover on the pads flaking off. Even with all this I'm extremely satisfied with the V6's. I've owned more expensive headphones in the past and these do sound on par or at times a bit better than the higher end cans. For those who don't want to read all that: Pros: - Sound quality - Price - Comfortable - Relatively Lightweight - Very portable In Between: - Mixing - Producing - Takes a few days to 'break-in' Cons: - Feel like they can't withstand drops if you drop them on a certain side (ear cups facing down) - Don't swivel left to right, just up and down If your trying to decide between the MDR-V6's and the MDR-V7506, they're the exact same headphones as far as build goes. Sound quality wise there was little to no difference. If they felt like they could withstand drops to the floor, I would give them a 5/5. I feel 4/5 is a bit too low. 4.4/5 is my overall rating. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I've owned two pairs of V6 headphones over the last 10 years and they've been some of the best investments I've ever made. I use my nice pair for desktop listening, while my aged beater pair with crumbling foam earpads (hey, they're nearly 10-years old and have seen thousands of hours of use) are used exclusively for the garage. Sound quality is solid, great bass and clear mids and highs...comfort is wonderful, but any headphone can become irritating when worn for eight hours straight. The coiled cord is also a bonus for desktop use, it lets you swivel around in your chair without excess cord getting caught up in your chair's wheels.

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I use it for: mixing music with DAW I compared a Sony MDR-V6, AKG K271MkII and Sennheiser HD-280 Pro side by side. All 3 are high quality monitor headphones. I use it for mixing music and so my chief concern is the true reproduction of sound over the hearing spectrum. I played all of they through an ONKYO Hi-Fi set. According to my subjective hearing experience, Sennheiser HD-280 is having the least bass sound. Sony MDR-V6 and AKG K271MkII is about the same regarding bass reproduction. Other than the very slight difference in bass reproduction, I don't find obvious difference regarding the sound. One thing I discovered is that the AKG K271MkII is quietest of them all. With my setup, it is capable of producing the smallest volumn. It has also the least noise. With the other 2, there is wh ... ite noise even with the volumn all down to zero. The noise from Sony MDR-V6 being the most noticeable among the three. I don't know why there is the noise. When I use a Behringer headphone amp, all the noise is gone. I'm not sure is it due to the headphones or the hi-fi or the amp. I would recommend Sony MDR-V6 among the 3 for studio monitoring purpose because of the very similar or near identical sound performance yet it is the cheapest. If money is not the problem, I'll choose AKG K271MkII because it has extra and easily replaceable chord and better earpads. But does it worth the extra a few hundred USD? You decide. Mind you that one of the plastic caps that have the L and R marking on AKG K271MkII was broken after a few weeks of use. It can be easily repaired by instant glue though. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.Review: I bought these to use with my PC because I needed a solution to blast my music and play videogames loudly without annoying my family through our paper-thin walls. It's been over a week now and these headphones work great. I'm not a complete audiophile, but I do hear well and these headphones have allowed me to listen into all the little details I couldn't hear with my iPod earplugs. I don't receive any distortion playing rock on the highest volume I can tolerate. Generally any distortion I do hear are from bad recordings and poorly encoded songs. I love the simple, straight forward design without the gaudy decorations and frills a lot of new/low price headphones seem to have nowadays. I definitely like the single, coiled cord that comes out of the left cup, instead of both cups then conver ... ging into one. I sort of feel uneasy about the plastic encasing that encases the cups and the cup hinges, but they feel sturdy enough for in-home use. It fits well around my head and ears and like other reviewers have said, it gets warm but not unbareable. It keeps a lot of sound out, but not 100%. Folds up nice, but the bag it comes with doesn't close well with a draw-string (I'm not using it). I'd definitely would recommend these to a first-time buyer who wants good quality with a relatively low price. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Sony MDR V6 - headphones - Ear-cup, Binaural
Item.ReviewTitle: Listen to music the way its meant to be heard.
Item.Review: I've owned a pair for a year & a half. These headphones can make you hear sounds in your music which you never thought existed. The resolution of different instruments is nothing short of amazing. There's no extra punch in the bass and you'll get to hear the clear tight bass only where the musician intended you to (i.e. high quality precise bass). Be it techno, metal, classic or jazz, you hear the sound the way it was made. But be clear with the concept that these are not magic headphones !!!! You only get to hear what you input. So, if you play low bitrate music files, you get to hear low quality sound. But play FLAC or 320 kbps mp3 files and you get to hear sounds from heaven (BE CAREFUL!! You could die from sheer pleasure :D) The only bad thing, as I mentioned in the beginning, is t ... he original earpads. Mine got worn out within the first year. Then I bought the Beyer Dynamic Velour Earpads, which actually doubled the hearing pleasure. My advice would be to buy the Beyer Dynamic earpads as soon as you buy the headphones and replace the original ones. expand » « collapse
